Award.AwardTitle: Genetic Regulation and Divergence of Developmental Plasticity in Pristionchus nematodes
Award.AbstractNarration:
"Developmental plasticity" is the ability of creatures with identical genes to vary in response to cues from the environment. This plasticity is thought to allow evolution to occur faster because it allows a species to have multiple traits. We don't yet know of many genes that allow some creatures to have this plasticity. This project will study a set of genes that create plasticity in the nematode worm Pristionchus pacificus. This worm has different mouth structures and behaviors depending on crowding and availability of food. The research will determine the function of these genes and how they interact, and it will reconstruct how these genes have evolved in related species that don't have developmental plasticity. The results of the research will show how developmental plasticity operates and changes at the level of individual genes. In addition, the investigators will train undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral students in biological research spanning the fields of genetics, developmental biology, and evolution. The research will augment two successful science outreach programs established at Indiana University: a) the PI will host and mentor underrepresented minority high-school students in their own research project, collect data, and present findings at an annual poster conference; b), the PI will help high-school teachers to develop and implement projects, experiments, and activities as classroom resources to improve the teaching and learning of state life science standards.

This project will build a functional genetic understanding of how development responds to diverse environmental settings, specifically through the production of discrete, alternative phenotypes (i.e., polyphenism). The objectives of the research are twofold. First, it will characterize the genetic factors and pathway that constitute a developmental switch for a polyphenism in the model nematode Pristionchus pacificus, by means of: (i) cloning and determining the spatial expression of genes that act downstream of a known polyphenism switch gene (eud-1), and; (ii) empirically determining how the interactions between their products form an environmentally responsive switch. Second, the research will determine how these factors change or assume new functions with the divergence of polyphenism regulation. Specifically, the research will reconstruct the evolutionary history of these factors via: (i) inferring patterns of sequence evolution and identifying potential functional variants, and; (ii) using reverse genetics in other species to perform comparative functional tests of those factors. Through analysis of a genetic pathway forming a developmental switch and the evolutionary divergence of its components, this research project will pioneer a functional genetic analysis of how developmental plasticity - specifically, a polyphenism - responds to environmental inputs, and how its regulation changes over evolutionary time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Traits in multicellular organisms are often not just specified by the genome: they can also be strongly influenced by the environment experienced during development and growth. In the most extreme cases, different environments can promote alternative, non-overlapping forms of a trait, a phenomenon known as polyphenism. The goal of the funded research was to determine how such a developmental response is regulated at the level of specific genes.

This project used a nematode model system, specifically one (Pristionchus species) with polyphenism and amenable to laboratory genetic techniques, to describe how a developmental 'switch' can translate environmental cues to differences in a trait's form. As a result, the research (i) revealed a genetic mechanism and logic for how trait-specific polyphenism is regulated and (ii) reconstructed how differences in polyphenism's molecular components underlie observed differences in the developmental response both within and among species.

The project resulted in several major findings. First, it produced a suite of genetic mutants that cause the loss of polyphenism, thereby enabling the study -- both during and beyond the life of the award -- of how specific genes influence polyphenism. Among the genes affected was one that encodes a nuclear receptor, which controls polyphenism following the activity of an enzyme (sulfatase) produced by other cells. This suggested a model for intercellular signaling and was among the first studies to describe how multiple genetic components regulate a trait-specific polyphenism in animals. Second, the research identified another gene, which encodes a sulfotransferase, whose characterization (i) linked a model for polyphenism regulation directly to the trait it controls, (ii) showed how dosage-dependent genetic interactions can influence the threshold for alternative forms of a trait, and (iii) provided a genetic explanation for how such developmental responses evolve. Third, the research linked the identified polyphenism switch-genes to their ultimate targets, i.e., the environmentally sensitive genes that produce the differences between alternative forms of a trait. Part of achieving this result was the production of large, genome-wide (transcriptomic) resources that have been deposited in public databases. Fourth, the research showed how a regulatory gene specialized, in its evolutionary history, to control a polyphenism switch. Fifth, the research reconstructed the evolutionary histories of multiple polyphenism regulators, including through gene duplications and molecular sequence changes, relative to the evolutionary origins of polyphenism itself.

The award also resulted in major training and educational impacts. First, it provided two postdoctoral researchers and one Master's student with training in developmental genetics and evolutionary biology. Second, it trained 11 undergraduate students through their participation in semi-independent research projects (including one Honors thesis), in which the students learned and practiced techniques for experimental design, genetics, molecular biology, and statistical and inference-based methods. Third, the research involved seven high-school students over the course of the award. This educational effort was part of an outreach program that brought high-performing minority students to the laboratory for resident, mentored research stays. Fourth, the award brought eight high-school teachers from across Indiana to the laboratory for resident workshops, through which resource-light teaching modules, including experiments with live nematodes in the classroom, were developed to enhance state teaching standards.
